title: What to Expect After Your Child Gets Vaccines
author: WebMD Editorial Contributors
description: It's vaccine time for your little one. What should you expect once it's over? Learn what's normal after immunization, and what isn't.
cleaned_text: like [polio](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/polio-vaccine-ipv), [measles](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/measles-mumps-and-rubella-mmr-vaccine), and [whooping cough](https://www.webmd.com/children/whooping-cough-symptoms-treatment). But like all medicines, they can sometimes come with side effects. Most of the time, these reactions are normal and harmless. Knowing what's common and what's not will help put your mind at ease after your child's next round of shots. Normal Reactions to Vaccines These drugs are made using parts of the diseases they protect your child from, but they don't cause the disease itself. They tell your child's body to make [blood](https://www.webmd.com/heart/anatomy-picture-of-blood) proteins called [antibodies](https://www.webmd.com/baby/antibody-testing) to fight off those diseases. For example, after a [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) for [whooping cough](https://www.webmd.com/children/pertussis-whooping-cough-10/slideshow-prevent-pertussis), if your child were to come into contact with the real illness, their body would recognize it and have the right tools to attack it. Mild reactions after a vaccine show that it's working. These symptoms are a sign that your child's body is making new antibodies. Normally, these reactions go away on their own within a few days. The most common effects you might see include: - Tenderness or redness at the shot site - Slight swelling at the shot site - Fussiness - Low-grade fever [Trouble or excessive sleeping](https://www.webmd.com/sleep-disorders/default.htm) Sometimes the DTaP and pneumococcal vaccines can cause other reactions, like: - Swelling of one whole leg or arm Much less common reactions include: [Vomiting](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-nausea-vomiting) - Drowsiness - Loss of appetite These are also normal side effects that should go away without any kind of treatment. Ask your doctor about appropriate dosing of pain and fever reducers. When to Call the Doctor If your child is allergic to certain vaccines, you'd notice signs that something is wrong. Typically, these reactions happen quickly after a vaccine, within a few minutes or hours. A good rule of thumb is to watch for anything that seems unusual, like mood or behavior change, [high fever](https://www.webmd.com/first-aid/fevers-causes-symptoms-treatments), or [weakness](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/tc/weakness-and-fatigue-topic-overview). Severe reactions are rare. Only 1 in 1 million children have them. Still, it's important to know what symptoms your doctor needs to know about, so you can get help for your child. Some specific signs to look for include: [Breathing problems](https://www.webmd.com/lung/breathing-problems-causes-tests-treatments)like [wheezing](https://www.webmd.com/asthma/tc/asthma-and-wheezing-topic-overview) - Hoarseness [Hives](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/guide/skin-conditions-hives-urticaria-angioedema) - Pale color - Weakness - Fast heartbeat [Dizziness](https://www.webmd.com/first-aid/understanding-dizziness-basics) - Swelling in the face or throat - Fever over 105 F [Seizures](https://www.webmd.com/epilepsy/understanding-seizures-basics) Another sign of a possible problem is if your baby or child cries uncontrollably for 3 hours or longer. In extremely rare cases, some vaccines may lead to [coma](https://www.webmd.com/brain/coma-types-causes-treatments-prognosis), long-term seizures, or permanent [brain damage](https://www.webmd.com/brain/brain-damage-symptoms-causes-treatments). These are unlikely reactions. In fact, doctors are trying to find out whether these and other serious side effects were caused by vaccines or for other reasons. If you notice any serious symptoms that concern you after your child's vaccines, call 911 or get your child to a hospital right away.
